data.text: Bike mechanic here- If you have a new bike, is your chain new too? Chains come pre-lubed and if you just put the wet lube on a new chain then you have over-lubed your chain and you will have to clean it more often. That being said, just wipe off any excessive grit with a rag or even paper towel. The rag won't run "clean" and then when you are done with your tour you can pop the quick-link and do a deeper clean with a chain degreaser and reapply the wet then.

data.text:
Don't bother trying to keep it pristine, just keep it wet, since a wet layer of oily fine silt actually helps insulate it from worse things AND helps it derail easier during gear changes. Just hand-back-pedal while wiping off the worst boogers with a paper towel, then re-oil it, perhaps before each day's ride. The more often you oil it, the less oil it will take to re-wet it. You normally don't need to spend more than a few seconds wiping, & then a few more seconds oiling. The whole process may be less than 60 seconds once you become proficient. I would not again (though I did) wash, rinse, dry & relube a chain except after some gritty catastrophe. If you are really paranoid about chain wear, obtain a chain wear measurement tool & use it frequently. They're small, lightweight & inexpensive. Don't forget to change your (chainring & cassette) teeth at every 2nd chain replacement. https://www.ebay.com/itm/133859272462?mkcid=16&mkevt=1&mkrid=711-127632-2357-0&ssspo=rdohvrffr0w&sssrc=2047675&ssuid=YH5WEKQ0SZ-&widget_ver=artemis&media=COPY
